awd_titl_txt: Standard: Learning NAGPRA: Cultivating Ethical Practice to Implement the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act
awd_abstract_narration:
The Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA, 43 CFR 10) constitutes human rights legislation enacted by Congress in 1990 to establish the rights of federally recognized U.S. tribes to request repatriation of ancestral human remains, funerary objects, sacred objects, and objects of cultural patrimony. The law requires scientists in archaeology, anthropology and museums to consult with tribes to assess cultural affiliations, prepare documentation, and conduct repatriations. Scientists initially saw NAGPRA and subsequent repatriation and reburial of collections as deleterious to research goals, and some still do. Many continued their research as though nothing had changed, despite the federal mandate. This project targets a gap between indigenous and non-native stakeholders by looking at how repatriation ethics are learned, comparing how professionals at Western scientific institutions learn about NAGPRA with how professionals at indigenous institutions and tribal colleges gain this understanding.  Tribal colleges are engaged as intellectual consultants in the project. We use ethnographic methods and communication studies to research ethics in this age of repatriation, and a collegium format to bring interdisciplinary multi-cultural stakeholders together to assess learning, address the potential of professional codes of ethics to aid practice, and evaluate the potential for curricula to move the repatriation-uncertain to the realm of repatriation partner. 

Museums, universities, and cultural resource management companies all need personnel that understand how NAGPRA works and how it can inform and guide ethical and respectful research in archaeology and anthropology. Better understanding of indigenous perspectives on repatriation may help scientists to overcome barriers to developing scholarship with tribal partners. Resistance to NAGPRA and the consultation it requires has slowed the development of applied research that might assist indigenous groups in meeting tribal goals. NAGPRA compliance that acts as an entree to collaboration has the potential to transform biological anthropology and archaeology for the 21st century. Resources that have been tested and aggregated into an open-access setting can be used internationally as indigenous people across the globe increasingly seek control over not only ancestral remains and material culture, but also heritage and representation. In addition, the collegium structure may find use in other situations in which indigenous and westernized scientific knowledge are combined. Promoting change in ethical practices at institutions whose duty is to repatriate can change the nature of relationships between scientists and descendants, and may contribute to future innovative partnerships with descendant communities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: ETHICS EDU FOR SCI & ENG PROG

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: ETHICS EDU FOR SCI & ENG PROG

por.por_cntn:
Learning NAGPRA is an ethics and learning-focused project that brought over 75 Native American and non-native scholars, educators, professionals, and students together to address a need for better understandings and practice in complying with the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA). The law was passed in 1990 and gave federally recognized Indigenous nations a pathway for claiming ancestral remains and cultural objects from institutions that receive federal funding. Compliance with the law was slow in coming for many institutions who lagged in consultation with tribes. Twenty-five years after passage, many faculty and students at institutions remained confused about the law, its provisions, and its critical importance to Indigenous people. Learning NAGPRA researched the reasons for sluggish compliance, and worked collaboratively to create curriculum materials to prepare non-Indigenous professionals for repatriating ancestral remains and cultural objects taken from graves.

Project researchers started by conducting baseline survey research to indentify experience, needs, and opinions about the practice and implications of NAPGRA. A survey of students in relevant courses (anthropology, museum studies, Native American Studies) and of faculty teaching these courses revealed a desire for addtional resources and more coverage of the subject in college curriculum. The project team also surveyed professional archaeologists, whose work on federal or tribal lands is impacted by provisions of the law requiring plans to manage new discoveries of ancestral remains or funerary objects. This study also identified a need for more instructional materials. The team also conducted a study of eight college courses held at mainstream and tribal-serving institutions to gauge changes in understanding when repatriation-related content was introduced.

The project team convened three collaborative Collegium meetings over three years to outline and address curriculum needs. Indigenous scholars and professionals from across the country worked collaboratively with non-native faculty and musem personnel. Each Collegium meeting included four to six graduate students, Indigenous and non-Indigenous. Four topics were agreed to be the most important to address, and Collegium participants formed four working groups. The first group developed ideas and content about Indigenous and non-Indigenous worldviews that come into play in the process of repatriation. The second group developed materials related to the contexts in which repatriation through NAGPRA happens, addressing the reality of historical trauma and its effect on Indigenous people. A third group wrote case studies taken from both actual and hybrid (based on real events but fictionalized) situations. A fourth group worked on materials for practicing professional archaeologists, developing a Webinar and an online self-paced course.

Materials developed will be available at no cost on the Learing NAGPRA website, along with an exhaustive list of resources, and information about the project and its participants. The project makes information and research about NAGPRA, as well as new curriculum, readily available to students, tribal members, and organizations. The Learning NAGPRA project also serves to increase the awareness of graduate students who may be helping the next generation of museum professionals and faculty to implement repatriation of ancestral individuals and their belongings to their desdendants.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2021
Modified by: April Sievert
